DoctorProfile.title: DoctorProfile
DoctorProfile.description: Represents a doctor's profile within the Praxis Online application.

id.description: Unique identifier for the DoctorProfile entity.

biography.description: A short biography of the doctor.

imageUrl.description: URL of the doctor's profile image.

ContactFormSubmission.title: ContactFormSubmission
ContactFormSubmission.description: Represents a submission from the contact form.

id.description: Unique identifier for the ContactFormSubmission entity.

name.description: The name of the person submitting the form.

email.description: The email address of the person submitting the form.

message.description: The message content of the form submission.

submissionDate.description: The date and time the form was submitted.

SymptomCheck.title: SymptomCheck
SymptomCheck.description: Represents a symptom check performed by a patient.

id.description: Unique identifier for the SymptomCheck entity.

symptoms.description: The symptoms entered by the patient.

possibleDiagnosis.description: The AI-powered possible diagnosis based on the symptoms.

checkDate.description: The date and time the symptom check was performed.

params.name: doctorProfileId
params.description: The unique identifier for the doctor profile.

definition.description: Stores contact form submissions from users.

params.name: contactFormSubmissionId
params.description: The unique identifier for the contact form submission.

definition.description: Stores records of symptom checks performed by patients.

params.name: symptomCheckId
params.description: The unique identifier for the symptom check record.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to organize data for the Praxis Online application, focusing on doctor profiles, contact form submissions, and symptom checks. Each entity is stored in its own top-level collection for clarity and scalability. This structure facilitates straightforward security rules and queries.

*   `doctor_profiles`: Stores doctor profiles. No specific authorization requirements are mentioned, implying open access or managed via backend.
*   `contact_form_submissions`: Stores contact form submissions. Admin access is implied, so security rules should restrict write access.
*   `symptom_checks`: Stores symptom check records. User-specific or open access, depending on requirements.

This design achieves authorization independence because there are no subcollections that inherit authorization context from their parent. Each collection is treated independently.

QAPs are supported using segregation; each entity type has its own collection. The security rules will determine list access.
